page.title: 09Guilsborough Grammar School
page.content: This is a fine example of {jacobean} architecture and is the most striking building in the village. Built by Sir John Langham Bart of Cottesbrooke, founded in 1668. The headmaster's salary was 50 pounds per annum,2 ushers at 20 pounds per annum and 80 pounds kept by the trustees for repairs.It provided for 50 youths from Guilsborough,Cold Ashby, Cottesbrooke and a 4 mile radius. By 1870 the boarders were down to 7 youths. Fees in 1825 were 25 guineas per year. It was closed in 1839 and remained in decay for 19 years. Restored and re-opened in 1856.Closed in 1909.By 1929 partly used as flats, partly village hall. Now divided into three modernised flats,one further flat in the process of restoration and part still to be restored,the outside has remained unchanged.
